results.title: Twenty-Eight Up: Prog.1: Pt.1&2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Twenty eight up continues the World in action series, following the development and changing attitudes of a group of British children every seven years, they are now twenty eight. This program talks to Tony, Bruce and Suzi.

results.title: 7 plus seven
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Fourteen children from a variety of school backgrounds, interviewed in 1964 for television about their hopes and aspirations, are followed up seven years later. Extracts from the first program, made when the children were seven years old, are shown and the children comment on any changes in their ideas.

results.title: 7 Days in September
results.creator_credit: Steven Rosenbaum and Broadcast News Networks
results.brief_description: This moving, if rudimentarily filmed documentary, is a collective account of ‘September 11, 2001’ and that day’s impact on a variety of New Yorkers. The filmmakers utilise an array of original footage shot over that week by professionals and by amateurs; they also interview an array of people who lived in New York at the time who describe their own responses and the unusual occurrences witnessed. The narrative focuses on the feel in New York over the week: the mood on the street, impromptu prayer sessions that were conducted, for example, as well as debates that raged between strangers; the clean up effort and the way that people pulled together, helping each other, making donations, giving blood, and providing emotional support. Whilst in no way an analysis of the calamity, the filmmakers eloquently capture the small stories. The work in a minor way, also addresses the role and the dilemma of any documentary filmmaker caught up in a tragedy - to film or not to film and at what stage does observation of a grand-scale catastrophe cross over into exploitation and opportunism.

results.title: A Better way
results.brief_description: In order to keep Canada’s vast quantities of mail moving, Canada Post dug around for a suitable solution. They came up with MAPP (Major Area Postal Plant), an ingenious, highly complex, streamlined system that relies on the postal code for efficient operation. The postal code relies on you and me, the mailing public, for inclusion in the address. The film tells what happens when a piece of mail is set on its course. No other credits available.

results.title: Seven up
results.creator_credit: Paul Almond, Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “World in action”.
Life viewed by Britain’s seven year olds. They give their views on life, leisure, love, marriage, colour prejudice, education, money and their ambitions for the future.

results.title: A Banking career
results.creator_credit: Harley H. Davidson, Frederick Daniel and Artransa Films
results.brief_description: Illustrates the various functions of a bank; the daily routine of business, and the responsibility of various bank officers. The latter part of the film lists the various advantages of making banking a career, mentioning rates of pay, special bonuses, opportunities for advancement, medical and sick leave benefits, pensions on retirement and the social life among bank personnel.

results.title: 35 up
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
The fifth in a series of remarkable documentaries which explore the lives of a diverse group of people who come before the cameras every seven years to be interviewed. Approaching middle-age the adults in this film are now settled in their lives, not completely fulfilled, but no longer so confident in the possibility of dreams coming true. Born into different social classes and different kinds of families, the adults in “35 Up” are candid about their experiences of divorce, having children, failure and death. The power of this film is that as we watch the children grow into adults we are made to ask ourselves challenging questions about the nature of family, community, heredity, class and human will. The success of the documentary has been such that it is now much imitated by film-makers across the globe.
